Graphic abstract Cyclic voltammetry of activated carbon/cobalt hexacyanoferrate composite as electrode materials for symmetric coin cells in sodium sulfate aqueous electrolyte. Electronic micrographs shows composite morphology and porous structure of cobalt hexacyanoferrate. We report here the activated carbon and cobalt hexacyanoferrate composite, which is applied as the electrode materials in symmetric supercapacitors containing a 1.0 M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte. This novel material combines high specific surface area and electrochemical stability of activated carbon with the redox properties of cobalt hexacyanoferrate, resulting in maximum specific capacitance of 329 F g−1 with large voltage working window of 2.0 V. Electrochemical studies indicated that cobalt hexacyanoferrate introduces important pseudocapacitive properties accounting for the overall charge-storage process, especially when I < 0.5 A g−1. At lower gravimetric currents (e.g., 0.05 A g−1) and up to 1.0 V, the presence of cobalt hexacyanoferrate improves the specific energy for more than 300%. In addition, to better understanding the energy storage process we also provided a careful investigation of the electrode materials under dynamic polarization conditions using the in situ Raman spectroscopy and synchrotron light X-ray diffraction techniques. Interesting complementary findings were obtained in these studies. We believe that this novel electrode material is promising for applications regarding the energy-storage process in pseudocapacitors with long lifespan properties. Keywords Operando studies Raman XRD synchrotron light Cobalt hexacyanoferrate Activated carbon High specific capacitance 1 Introduction Alternatives for burning fossil fuels have attracted a lot of attention for the global economy, which demands technologies with good cost-effectiveness that fulfil the sustainable requirements. In this sense, several strategies for energy production and storage have been highlighted, such as fuel cells, batteries, and supercapacitors (SCs). In the field of energy storage and supply, SCs show interesting properties such as power energy storage systems with high specific capacitance, long lifespan, high specific power, no memory effects, and safer than most available batteries [1]. One of the greatest challenges of research in the SCs field is how to increase the specific energy (E) of the devices. Since energy is directly proportional to the capacitance and the square of the voltage, many strategies have been employed in developing new systems that present high specific capacitance and/or a large voltage window where the electrolyte is stable. This involves the preparation of new electrode materials tailoring their energy storage capabilities, as well as to carry out studies about the interaction of the electroactive surface sites with the electrolyte species. Good interactions between electrode materials, ions, and solvents used in SCs are of paramount importance for improving the performance of these devices [2]. Activated carbon (AC) is the porous material most applied as electrodes for SCs due to its high surface area (e.g., from 600 to 2500 m2 g−1), chemical stability, low cost, and renewable nature [3]. Several synthesis strategies have been employed to obtain good ACs from biomass and organic residues [4,5], as is the case of chemical activation [6]. Also, AC-based composite materials for the energy storage devices can be synthesized by the incorporation of redox-active species (e.g., transition metal oxides and intrinsically conducting polymers), resulting in a pseudocapacitive contribution to the overall electrode capacitance [7,8]. In principle, the use of redox-active species can enhance the specific capacitance of the AC-based electrodes but this strategy might present some drawbacks such as poor electrical conductivity, low specific power, and low cycling stability (e.g., short lifespan) [9]. Prussian blue (PB) and its analogues (PBAs) represent a class of compounds known as coordination polymers. These species are commonly produced by precipitation methods from a hexacyanoferrate solution composed of transition metal salts containing iron, cobalt, manganese, and copper [10]. The metal cations act as bridging ligands between the hexacyanoferrate moieties, producing porous frameworks that may be used to insert cations and small molecules such as dioxygen and hydrogen peroxide [11]. This feature has attracted interest in the field of catalysis [12,13], sensors [14,15], energy storage, and conversion [16–18]. However, these materials may suffer from low conductivity and chemical stability [19]. Specifically for the energy storage proposals, the large channels exhibited by PBAs are of great interest in increasing the diffusion path of the ions involved in the charge–discharge process [17,20]. Thus, PBAs have been applied as an electrode in energy storage devices such as batteries and supercapacitors. Several methodologies have been developed to increase material conductivity and surface area, for example by changing the synthetic procedures and metal composition [21]. However, these materials have some drawbacks including low life cycle, retention rates, and energy/power densities, as a result of several redox processes that occur at the electrode/electrolyte interface. In this sense, an alternative is to combine PBA with non-redox active materials that can accumulate charge from the electrochemical double-layer behavior and extract very fast electrons from PBA. Carbon-based materials such as activated carbon, hydrogels, nanotubes, and graphene can match these requirements, and have been explored in several electrode materials [21]. In this work, we report an easy method to synthesize a composite electrode material for applications in symmetric SCs containing AC and porous cobalt-based Prussian blue analog, named cobalt hexacyanoferrate (CoHCF). As far as we are concerned, the application of the porous CoHCF prepared as described herein regarding the use of symmetric carbon-based supercapacitors and an aqueous electrolyte has not been studied so far. In this sense, we take advantage of the high specific surface area and electrochemical stability of AC combined with the good redox-activity properties of CoHCF. Furthermore, we performed complementary operando studies under dynamic polarization conditions using the X-ray diffraction and Raman Spectroscopy techniques to get new insights about the fundamental processes accounting for the charge-storage process, as well as the possible occurrence of structural changes in the electrode material. 2 Experimental 2.1 Pre-treatment of the activated carbon (AC) Commercial activated carbon from Synth® (Brazil) was mixed with KOH in the weight ratio of 1:3, followed by heating in an oven at a rate of 5 °C min−1 up to reach 700 °C where the material was heated for 1.0 h. After that, AC was filtered using a vacuum line, and the product was rinsed with a 1.0 mol L−1 HCl solution until the neutral pH was obtained. After that, the solid was washed several times with distilled water and finally dried overnight in an oven at 50 °C [22]. 2.2 Synthesis of the porous cobalt hexacyanoferrate (CoHCF) Cobalt hexacyanoferrate was prepared using the procedure described elsewhere [23]. In short, a solution containing 0.40 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP from Synth® (Brazil)) and 0.01 g of manganese sulfate (MnSO4 from Synth® (Brazil)) was prepared using 10 mL of deionized water and 10 mL of ethanol, followed by stirring during 30 min. Then, 10 mL of a 0.03 mol L−1 K3[Fe(CN)6] solution were dropwise added in the reaction flask and the mixture was stirred overnight. After that, 10 mL of a 0.045 mol L−1 Co(NO3)2 solution were added to the reaction flask and stirred for 5.0 h at 50 °C. The solution was filtered, and the obtained solid material was rinsed with deionized water several times. The solid material was dried overnight in an oven at 50 °C. 2.3 Preparation of the symmetric coin cell using composite electrodes The composite electrodes used in the symmetric coin cell were prepared using a mixture of AC and CoHCF pastes. The AC paste contained activated carbon, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF from Aldrich® (Brazil)), and carbon black (CB, CABOT XC72R) in the weight ratio of 8:1:1, respectively. The paste containing the AC/CoHCF composite was prepared from CoHCF, AC, PVDF, and CB in the weight ratio of 4:4:1:1, respectively. Both pastes were prepared by dispersion of the compounds in DMSO (0.5 g in 1 mL DMSO) using an ultrasonic probe. After that, pastes were cast onto stainless-steel plates with 2 cm of diameter and dried overnight in an oven at 50 °C. The metallic substrates were used as the current collectors. Afterward, the symmetric coin cell was assembled using as the separator a cellulosic filter paper soaked with a 1.0 mol L−1 Na2SO4 aqueous solution. 2.4 Material characterization 2.4.1 SEM and TEM studies Electronic micrographs were obtained at the LNNano-CNPEM facilities. SEM micrographs of the carbon pastes were taken using a model F50 scanning electron microscope from FEI. TEM micrographs of the CoHCF particles were taken using a model 2100 MSC high-resolution transmission electron microscope from JEOL. Samples were dispersed in isopropanol using an ultrasonic bath and dropped on a TEM lacey carbon film supported on a copper mesh. 2.4.2 FTIR study Infrared spectra of CoHCF were registered using a model Vertex 70v spectrometer from Bruker in the range of 4000–400 cm−1. The measurements were performed in the attenuated total reflectance (ATR) mode. 2.4.3 XRD study X-ray diffractograms of the powder samples were obtained using a model X’Pert MPD Analytical X-ray diffractometer from Phillips (Cu K α = 0.15406 nm) in the 2θ-scale ranging from 5 to 60° at a rate of 0.02° min−1. 2.4.4 XPS study XPS spectra of the CoHCF powder samples were taken using a model SPECSLAB II (Phoibos-Hsa 3500 150, 9 channeltrons) spectrometer from SPECS, with Al K α source (E = 1486.6 eV) operating at 12 kV, pass energy (E pass) of 40 eV, with a 0.1 eV energy step, and acquisition time of 1 s per point. The residual pressure inside the analysis chamber was ~1 × 10−8 Torr. Scanning and high-resolution spectra were obtained in the energy range of 0–1200 eV, with a resolution of 1 and 0.1 eV, respectively. Data were analyzed using the Casa XPS software. The spectra accounting for the N 1s, Fe 2p 3/2, and Co 2p 3/2 signals were corrected using the bonding energy of C 1s at 284.8 eV, and the background noise was removed using a Shirley type polynomial function. 2.4.5 Electrochemical studies A model BCS-810 potentiostat/galvanostat from Bio-logic Science Instruments was used throughout. The electrochemical characterization of the symmetric coin cell was initiated using the cyclic voltammetry (CV) technique in the voltage ranges of 0–1.0 V and 0–2.0 V at different scan rates. Then, galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) experiments were accomplished in the current range of 0.145–14.50 mA and in the voltage ranges of 0–1.0 V and 0–2.0 V. The capacitance retention was evaluated by cycling the coin cell at 0.5 A g−1 during 10 thousand GCD cycles in the voltage range of 0–1.0 V. The specific capacitance (C), energy (E), and power (P) were calculated, after registering twenty consecutive charge–discharge cycles, using the Eqs. (1)–(3) [2]: (1) C = I m dV dt F g - 1 where I is the discharge (cathodic) current, m is the overall mass of the composite material present on both electrodes, and dV/dt is the slope in the linear region of the discharge curve. (2) E = C V 2 2 × 10 3 3600 W h k g - 1 (3) P = E Δ t W k g - 1 where Δ t is the discharge time interval. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments were performed after successive 500 GCD cycles, up to a total number of 8500 cycles, to evaluate possible changes on the coin cell properties. Impedance data were taken at 0.5 V d.c. bias. The frequency range used was 10 kHz to 10 mHz using a sinusoidal perturbation with an amplitude of 10 mV (peak-to-peak) to ensure linear conditions on the impedance response. 2.4.6 Operando studies The in situ (operando) characterization of the composite electrodes under dynamic polarization conditions was carried out using an EL-CELL® (ECC-Opto-Std with XRD configuration and Polyester (PET) window) having similar electrochemical characteristics of the coin cell used in the conventional electrochemical studies [24]. In this experimental setup, aluminum foils were used as the current collectors and as the support for the electrode material in the same manner as was previously described in this work for the stainless-steel substrate. X-ray diffraction studies were performed applying synchrotron light operating at an energy of 7 keV (λ = 0.1769 nm) in Bragg-Brentano geometry using the XPD beamline at the LNLS-CNPEM. Diffractograms were collected in the 2θ-scale with the variable range using a Mythen – 1 K linear detector (Dectris) installed at 1 m from the sample. Raman spectra were taken using a Renishaw inVia equipment where a 633 nm excitation wavelength was applied and focused on a single spot with a 50× objective lens. This means that all measurements with a specific electrolyte were performed at the same place/point. The symmetric coin cell was composed of two AC/CoHCF composite electrodes separated by a cellulosic mesoporous membrane soaked with the aqueous electrolyte. After collecting each spectrum, 10 μL of the electrolyte were added to avoid dryness. All Raman spectra were obtained while running the cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments. In this case, a model VersaSTAT 3 potentiostat from Ametek was used to obtain the electrochemical findings. Before starting the ‘in situ’ (operando) experiments, twenty consecutive voltammetric charge–discharge cycles were taken at 500 mV s−1 using a voltage range of 0.0–2.0 V. All Raman spectra were collected with 1 accumulation and 80 s of exposure time. The laser energy was 10% of the total energy to prevent electrode damage. Raman shifts were calibrated using a single crystal diamond sample and the temperature inside the EL-CELL® was adjusted to 23.1 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ex situ studies: SEM, TEM, FTIR, XRD, and XPS Micrographs of activated carbon are presented in Fig. S1. As seen, it was possible to verify the material was obtained as plates with a length of ca. 20 µm. As similar structures were not observed in the composite material, there is strong evidence from findings shown in Fig. 1 that the ultrasonic probe promoted their reduction to smaller particles, which is desirable for the charge-storage process. The porous PBA particles were formed using templates as the sacrificial structures. This procedure was developed considering the different solubility products of the coordination polymers, which allows the substitution of manganese cations by others such as cobalt, without modifying the original cubic shape of the particles [23,25]. Micrographs of the CoHCF powder are presented in Fig. 1(a). As can be observed, the material has well-defined cubic nanoparticles, ranging from 150 to 500 nm (e.g., average size of ~300 nm). Fig. 1(b) shows the micrographs of the AC/CoHCF composite deposited onto the metallic substrate, revealing a homogeneous distribution between carbon and the cobalt hexacyanoferrate as a result of the adequate preparation of the carbon paste. The porous structure of the CoHCF nanoparticles was micrographed by TEM (Fig. 1(c)). Cubic particles have internal channels, increasing the electrochemically active surface area available for the charge and energy storage processes. FTIR analysis of CoHCF is presented in Fig. S2(a) and revealed a strong absorption band at 2115 cm−1 which can be ascribed to the cyanide stretching mode that is typical of Prussian blue analogue structures. According to the literature [26,27], these findings indicate the formation of a cyanide bridging between cobalt and iron. Besides, there are peaks with moderate intensity located at 3363 and 1603 cm−1, which indicate the presence of water trapped inside the lattice. The structural properties of the composite material were investigated using the XRD technique (see Fig. S2(b)). The diffraction pattern obtained is in agreement with the well-known XRD findings reported for cobalt hexacyanoferrate [27–29]. It is worth mentioning that phases due to other species were not found thus indicating the absence of impurities in the composite sample. Results from the XPS analysis accomplished for the CoHCF powder are presented in Fig. 2 , evidencing the presence of elements on the material and to obtain more information about the chemical bonds. The analysis of the carbon C 1s region of the spectrum indicated the occurrence of peaks at 284.7 and 288.2 eV, attributed to CC and OCO bonds. Also, a peak at 286.4 eV was attributed to the CN bonds expected in the CoHCF structure. As one would expect only the CN peaks to be observed in the CoHCF analysis, we attributed the other carbon related peaks to remaining traces of PVP used in the synthesis step. The analysis of the N 1s region also confirmed the existence of this bond with a peak at 398.2 eV. The Fe 2p region showed peaks at 722.9 and 710.2 eV that can be assigned to the Fe2+ species [12,26,30]. Finally, analysis of the Co 2p region showed two peaks at 787.8 and 782.8 eV which were assigned to the presence of Co2+ and Co3+ species, respectively, indicating partial oxidation of the cobalt sites present in the coordination polymer [12,30]. XPS from AC is well known and was reported elsewhere [31]. 3.2 Electrochemical studies Metal hexacyanoferrates represent a class of compounds with well-known redox properties [18,19,26] which are of great interest to introduce pseudocapacitive contributions in the activated carbon (AC) electrode. Both iron and cobalt species can undergo redox reactions followed by the inclusion of sodium cations inside the material framework as represented by Eq. (4) [28,32]: (4) C o 3 Fe CN 6 2 + 2 N a + + 2 e - → N a 2 C o 3 Fe CN 6 2 In addition to the open structure of metal hexacyanoferrates, the synthetic method described in this work provided the formation of porous cobalt hexacyanoferrate nanoparticles, which can increase the electrochemically active surface area of the composite material. The electrochemical characterization of the symmetric coin cell was first performed using cyclic voltammetry (CV). Data in Fig. 3 are presented in such a way that on the left-hand side we have the CVs from AC while on the right-hand side we showed the voltammetric behavior of the AC/CoHCF composite electrodes in 1.0 M Na2SO4. The important characteristics of CVs for well-behaved supercapacitors were previously discussed, focusing on the important differences between true capacitors and battery-like systems [33]. Here, we want to investigate the dynamics of the Na+ and/or PBA redox during (re)charging/discharging. The voltammograms (VCs) with a scan rate 5 and 10 mV s−1 showed good stability during the charge–discharge processes carried out for the voltage range of 0–1.0 V. Fig. 3(a) shows quasi-rectangular voltammetric curves which are commonly verified for AC-based (EDLCs) supercapacitors. In Fig. 3(b), one can observe that the redox peaks appear below 0.5 V. Up to 1.0 V, oxidation peaks can be distinguished. In addition, the pronounced gravimetric currents verified close to the cathodic vertex voltage in Fig. 3(b) are mainly due to the onset of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Since the anodic and cathodic voltammetric charges were equal, it is proposed that the surface reaction (e.g., 2H+ + 2e− → H2(ads)) behaves reversibly during the charge–discharge process. This behavior seems to indicate a small unbalanced in the masses used in the coin cell where the anode mass is slightly higher than the cathode mass. As a result, the discharge process involved the aforementioned surface Faradaic reaction. It is well-known that the charge stored in each electrode must be equal for coin cell devices (e.g., two-electrode systems). Thus under the restriction of balanced charges on both electrodes, the electrode systems must obey the relation m +/m − = C −ΔU −/C +ΔU +. In this sense, by controlling the masses of the anode and cathode we can dictate the polarization potential of each electrode during the charge–discharge process, which is not commonly measured in the absence of the third electrode used as the reference. Obviously, for symmetric devices, we must consider that m + = m − to avoid over polarization in a particular electrode with the concomitant involvement of a parasitic Fardaic process, as is the case of water-splitting. Fig. 3(c and d), referring to the AC/CoHCF composite, show the voltammetric profiles when the voltage range was extended to 2.0 V. As seen, in Fig. 3(d), the solid-state redox activity of the metallic sites occurred at ~0.4 V. As discussed elsewhere [12,34], up to 2.0 V (see Fig. 3(d)), there are two peaks that we attributed to the Fe3+/Fe2+ (~0.2 V) and Co3+/Co2+ (~0.4 V) redox transitions. These redox peaks, due to localized Faradaic processes trapped in the solid matrix, were considerably reduced in the range of 5–50 mV s−1, i.e., the peaks practically vanished due to the sluggishness of the solid-state redox transition reactions (SSRTR) involving the intercalation of Na+ ions which is controlled by diffusion occurring inside the porous electrode structure (see the Eq. (3)). It is quite interesting that the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) due to water-splitting did not occur close to the anodic vertex voltage. To confirm this hypothesis, we performed chronoamperometric studies holding the working voltage window at 2.0 V to observe the exponential capacitive current decay predicted for supercapacitors (e.g., I = (U/R esr)exp(−t/R esr C edl)) to rule out the presence of a superimposed Faradaic current due to the OER (Fig. S3). As seen, these studies confirmed the absence of the water-splitting. Similar findings were previously reported in the literature for supercapacitors based on Prussian blue analogues [35]. On the whole, the CV results seem to indicate that the present composite electrode material is quite promising for energy storage purposes. Galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) experiments were carried out to determine the specific capacitance, power, and energy for the symmetric coin cell. In this case, we presented a comparison of the performance verified for the AC and AC/CoHCF symmetric coin cells as a function of the applied gravimetric current and cell voltage. In this sense, Fig. 4 shows the GCD curves taken for the symmetric coin cell for the gravimetric current range of 0.05–1.0 A g−1. As can be seen, when a low gravimetric current of 0.01 A g−1 was used in the experiments, only the AC/CoHCF composite electrode polarized up to 1.0 V was able to reach the maximum voltage (Fig. S4). A comparison of the experimental findings obtained using a voltage range of 1.0 V revealed the presence of two distinct patterns for the GCD curves. In the case of the symmetric coin cell using AC electrodes, the typical almost triangular profile expected for well-behaved EDLCs was verified [36,37]. On the contrary, in the case of the AC/CoHCF composite electrodes, we observed a short non-linear region around 0.2 V due to the occurrence of the SSRTR involving cobalt (e.g., the Co3+/Co2+ redox couple) [34,38]. For the different coin cells polarized at 2.0 V, the GCD profiles are typical of those commonly verified for porous electrodes with the presence of a “distributed capacitance”. As a result, the discharge curves are characterized by non-linear U vs. t profiles since the concept of a single-valued capacitance does not make sense in the presence of interconnected and hierarchically distributed pores with different accessibilities to the ionic species [34,38]. In this sense, since the latter behavior involving a distributed capacitance was only verified at 2.0 V, we can propose that at higher polarization conditions the porous nature of the electrode material is pronounced due to partial activation of some narrower micropores due to a high electric field strength established at the electrode/solution interface. Therefore, the difference in the shape of GCD curves can indicate the occurrence of different mechanisms for the charge–discharge processes as a function of the applied voltage which can involve either an electrostatic process in different regions of the interconnected porous structure present in the AC matrix, as well as a near-surface or more deep reversible insertion of cations (e.g., Na+) in the CoHCF porous structure (see Eq. (3)). As a result, the profiles of the GCD curves verified for the composite electrodes reflect the combination of the redox properties exhibited by CoHCF and the intrinsic electrostatic process due to AC electrodes [36,37]. The Figures-of-merit extracted from the GCD study are gathered in Table 1 . We have also performed calculations involving normalization for the mass of CoHCF used in the coin cells and the results are presented in Table S1. As CoHCF is a material commonly used in battery-like systems, we have also reported the capacity values as obtained by the GCD curves, which data is presented in Fig. S5 and Table S2. The results showed that specific capacity values reached up to 91 mA h g−1, which is in agreement with previously reported results for other Prussian blue analogues [10]. However, it is worth mentioning that the typical peaked-shape CVs and the presence of a plateau in the GCD profiles were not observed in the present study. As cobalt hexacyanoferrate is mostly used as a battery electrode material in the literature reports, to transform it on a fast-charged electrode, we combine cobalt hexacyanoferrate with activated carbon, which is high surface area carbon with fairly well electrical conductivity and containing hierarchically interconnected pores. This technique helps to obtain a fast charge extraction from the cobalt hexacyanoferrate, resulting in a long lifespan (i.e., this process avoids passivation of the electrodes). Although CoHCF has been used in the literature mostly as a battery-type material, we must stress that, as seen from the Ragone plots (Fig. 5 (a) – see further discussion), that the composite synthesized in this work might be used with confidence as the electrode material for supercapacitors. Table 1 shows that the cobalt hexacyanoferrate introduced an important pseudocapacitive feature in the overall charge-storage process, especially when the current is not too high, i.e., better results are found when the current is smaller than 0.5 A g−1. Actually, at a lower gravimetric current (e.g., 0.05 A g−1) and voltage up to 1.0 V, the specific energy was improved more than 300% in the presence of CoHCF. When comparing the experiments performed at different voltage ranges, we verified that the highest specific capacitance of 329 F g−1 (or a capacity of 91 mAh g−1) was achieved at 0.01 A g−1 and 1.0 V. In principle, this behavior could be ascribed to the following factors: (i) The deviations from the R-C capacitive model described by a triangular behavior due to distortions in the GCD curves, and/or (ii) the presence water splitting with the formation of gases due to a catalyzed process induced by CoHCF at high cell voltages (U > 1.0 V) with concomitant blocking effects caused by the presence of bubbles trapped inside the pores [12,39]. However, the latter factor can be ruled out due to the chronoamperometric findings already discussed above (see Fig. S3), as well as by considering the long-term service life verified for the coin cells (e.g., the reversible cyclability was higher than 80 thousand cycles (please see Fig. 6 (c)). As seen, in most of the cases the highest values of the specific energy were verified for the AC/CoHCF composite electrodes at 2.0 V where maximum specific energy of 7.3 W h kg−1 was verified at 0.05 A g−1. Maximum specific power of ~2000 W kg−1 was verified at 1.0 A g−1 for the different symmetric coin cells. These findings are comparable to others previously verified for the hexacyanoferrate-based supercapacitors [23,27,32,35,40] where the highest values reported for the specific energy and specific power were 18.15 W h kg−1 (at 0.125 A g−1) and 2500 W kg−1 (at 2.5 A g−1), respectively. Based on the specific energy and power obtained for the symmetric coin cells, it was possible to obtain the corresponding Ragone plot, as presented in Fig. 5(a). This plot revealed values in agreement with those expected for supercapacitors. Also, the Ragone profile is also compatible with ‘battery-like’ systems thus indicating a possible application of the present composite electrode material in hybrid energy-storage electrochemical devices. Finally, the capacitance retention of the coin cell was evaluated by performing 10 thousand successive GCD cycles for the voltage range of 1.0 V using a gravimetric current of 0.5 A g−1 (see Fig. 5(b)). This potential range was chosen since it provided the highest specific capacitances in the previous studies already discussed in this work. These findings evidenced the great stability of the devices with capacitance retention of 98% after the long-term cycling process. Also, they are in good agreement with those previously reported for PBA-based supercapacitors [35]. Fig. 6 shows the results obtained from the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments for the symmetric coin cells. Both systems showed linear Nyquist plots for all frequencies as expected for supercapacitors. Deviations from the theoretical (ideal) phase angle of −90° indicated the presence of the frequency dispersion phenomenon intrinsic to rough/porous electrodes [41]. In this case, the impedance data can be simulated using the simple circuit R ESR–CPEedl, where R ESR is the equivalent series resistance and CPEedl (e.g., Z CPE = 1/Y 0(jω) n , where n ≈ 1 and C edl ≈ Y 0) is the “constant phase element” representing the non-ideal behavior of the electrical double-layer (EDL). The true values of C edl were extracted from the Y 0-values using the well-known Brugg-Sluyters formula (e.g., C edl = (Y 0)1/ n (1/R ESR)(1−1/ n )). A comparison between the EIS profiles referring to the different coin cells indicated that modification of AC with cobalt hexacyanoferrate did not cause significant modifications to the impedance behavior. To evaluate the effect of charge–discharge cycles on the coin cell properties, impedance measurements were accomplished after every 500 cycles for the AC/CoHCF symmetric coin cell (see Fig. 6(b and c)). The capacitance values obtained from the EIS analysis were considerably lower than those verified using the GCD method, i.e., a close inspection of the data in Table 1 and Fig. 6(c) revealed that the absolute values for the capacitance strongly depend on the particular method of analysis (GCD or EIS). This evident discrepancy can be understood considering that the true C edl-values extracted from the Y 0-parameter, which was used in the complex non-linear least squares (CNLS) method of simulation, using the Brugg-Sluyters formula can be considerably affected by the frequency dispersion phenomenon and the R ESR. Unfortunately, in several literature reports some authors erroneously assumed that C edl = Y 0 while in reality, one can verify that C edl ≪ Y 0 for systems exhibiting a pronounced “distributed capacitance” in the frequency domain due to the porous electrode behavior, i.e., when the phase angle is lower than 90°. In agreement with the previous findings obtained using the GCD method, a small decrease of the specific capacitance values was observed for the coin cell. We particularly believe that EIS provides more trustable results, especially when the GCD plots are not characterized by the ‘almost triangular profile’ characteristic of supercapacitors. However, this assertion can be applied only in the cases where the frequency dispersion phenomenon is almost negligible and, therefore, we can assume that C edl ≅ Y 0. It is worth mentioning that non-ideal GCD curves tend to overestimate the specific capacitance due to the absence of a true linear region during the discharge while the non-ideal EIS spectrum underestimates the correct evaluation of C edl from the CPE. Unfortunately, this important issue involving the study of non-ideal electrochemical systems is commonly disregarded in the literature [34,38]. As a result, several incoherences can be found considering the experimental findings reported for different electrode materials. One of the great current difficulties found in the literature is concerned with the correct (reliable) evaluation of the Figs.-of-merit for supercapacitors based on porous electrodes, i.e., in several cases, the experimental findings are erroneously treated as they were obtained for a perfect electrochemical system composed of ideally flat electrodes that obey to a good accuracy the basic laws of electrostatics initially proposed for passive electrical systems and in the absence of “dispersive effects” [34,38]. As can be seen, the ESR values slightly decreased during the cycling process. This behavior seems to indicate that the long-term charge–discharge process improved the conductivity of the composite electrode material due to a progressive insertion of the Na+ ions into the near-surface regions of the porous electrode structure. 3.3 Operando studies We performed a Raman probing study of the AC/CoHCF electrodes using a specially designed electrochemical cell. Before discussions regarding the electrode characterization under dynamic polarization conditions, ex-situ spectra of each composite material were obtained separately (Fig. S6). The spectrum of AC presents peaks at 1333 and 1603 cm−1 that are attributed to D and G bands, respectively, and are typical of carbon-based materials described elsewhere [42]. The spectrum of CoHCF showed a very strong absorption band at 2176 cm−1, which was attributed to the bending modes of the CN bond [26,28]. A spectrum of the modified aluminum support covered with the composite was obtained and showed that few modifications occur in the structure of both AC and CoHCF when preparing the carbon paste. An interesting feature is that CN stretching shifts its position from 2176 to 2147 cm−1 in the composite. From our best understanding, that is the proof of strong interaction between CoHCF and PVDF, which glue and stick together to activated carbon & carbon black. This shift position means that great ordering on around CN caused but charge transfer or strong adsorption (i.e., adsorption energy close to work function of material) of PVDF onto CoHCF. The Raman spectra of the AC/CoCoHCF composite electrode obtained under dynamic polarization conditions are presented in Fig. 7 . The charge–discharge process was carried out for the voltage range of 2.0 V using a 1.0 M Na2SO4 solution. A complete assignment of the observed bands is presented in Table 2 . As the charging process occurs, a lowering in the intensity of the D, G, and cyanide stretching bands were observed. A possible explanation for this behavior can be a partial blocking ofthe electrode surface to the laser incurred by adsorption of ions from the electrolyte. In addition, some previous spectral-electrochemical studies reported changes in the intensity of the cyanide band or shifts according to the applied voltage as a result of the redox processes that occur in the PBA structure [26,43]. As seen, the intensity of the band at 985 cm−1 corresponding to the sulfate stretching mode increased with the applied voltage in the present work. In principle, these findings suggest an increase in the concentration of the sulfate anions at the electrode/electrolyte interface during the charging process, which is visible using the Raman confocal microscope and expected from adsorption processes. During the discharging process, the bands observed at the beginning of the experiment appear gradually and the spectra returns to its initial state, except by the appearance of the band at 1400 cm−1, which we attributed to the glass window used in the experimental setup (please see Fig. S7). As evidenced from the close inspection of Fig. 8 , at the end of the discharging process the initial electrode conditions were recovered evidencing the reversibility of the fundamental physical and chemical processes (see the Eq. (3)). We also performed an XRD analysis of the composite electrode under dynamic polarization conditions to indirectly assess the intercalation process involving the Na+ ions, as well as the stability of the host material during the intermittent GCD charge–discharge cycles. The main peaks were attributed to the diffraction patterns of two possible structures of CoHCF, which are Co3[Fe(CN)6]2·H2O and Co2[Fe(CN)6]·2H2O. The trend of change observed for the intensity of the diffractogram peaks (Fig. 8(a)) can be explained considering the electrostatic interaction between the electrode and the electrolyte. At the beginning of the experiment, the AC/CoHCF composite was in contact with a high-concentration electrolyte solution (e.g., 1.0 M Na2SO4) and no diffraction peaks referring to the electrode material could be observed during the charging process where the anions from the electrolyte accumulate at the electrode/solution interface creating a surface excess (Γ anions) as was initially proposed by Gibbs (e.g., the Gibbs’ thermodynamic adsorption model). On the contrary, during the discharging step where the surface excess by the SO4 2− anions are progressively substituted by the surface excess by the Na+ cations, we verified that the diffractions peaks referring to CoHCF and the aluminum substrate could be detected. A couple of studies have reported more pronounced reversible shifts of the diffraction peaks referring to PBAs as a result of the intercalation/deintercalation of cations inside the structure and redox processes (see the Eq. (3)), which cause lattice contraction/expansion as a result of changes in the length of the chemical bonds of the coordination polymer [46,47]. Depending on the particular electrode material, new phases may be formed due to the conversion of the cubic to a rhombohedral structure [46]. In this sense, we observed small shifts while performing the charge–discharge experiments (Fig. 8(a)) which, at least in principle, permits to calculate the variation of the interplanar spacing during the dynamic polarization (Fig. 8(b)). However, as the differences in the interplanar distances were very small, it is not prudent from the scientific viewpoint to correlate the aforementioned XRD shifts with the occurrence of the intercalation–deintercalation of Na+ ions. In our opinion, possible explanations for small shifts are: (i) The particular (low) amount of CoHCF present in the AC-based electrodes, and/or (ii) the phase conversion does not occur in the nanometric or submicron particle domains; and/or (iii) hindrance of the Na+ accessibility into the CoHCF interplanar region. To get sharp peaks in the XRD diffractogram, samples need to exhibit an ordered structure at least of the size of the X-ray spot and in a depth containing a few layers of the material. Since these conditions might be not meet in practice, the XRD findings may evidence a lack of order to the Na+ partial penetration and adsorption in the composite material. Both behaviors were observed during the charge and discharge processes. From these condiserations, further studies are necessary to clarify this important issue. 4 Conclusions We report in this article on porous cobalt hexacyanoferrate that was combined with the activated carbon and then used as the composite electrodes in a symmetric supercapacitor. The coin cell was very stable in the aqueous electrolyte even for a high voltage of 2.0 V, while a maximum specific capacitance of 329 F g−1 was verified. An improvement of 300% in the performance of the device was verified in the presence of CoHCF. According to the Ragone plot, depending on the applied gravimetric current, the coin cell could operate in a dual behavior, i.e., either as a supercapacitor or a battery-like system. It was verified a 98% of capacitance retention after 10 thousand charge–discharge cycles accomplished during the GCD tests. Experimental findings extracted from the operando study indicated good stability of the composite electrode material during the charge–discharge cycles, thus allowing us to track the reversible behavior of the electrostatic and chemical processes involving the interaction between the ions from the electrolyte and the polarized electrode surface. coredata.dc:description: We report here the activated carbon and cobalt hexacyanoferrate composite, which is applied as the electrode materials in symmetric supercapacitors containing a 1.0 M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte. This novel material combines high specific surface area and electrochemical stability of activated carbon with the redox properties of cobalt hexacyanoferrate, resulting in maximum specific capacitance of 329 F g−1 with large voltage working window of 2.0 V. Electrochemical studies indicated that cobalt hexacyanoferrate introduces important pseudocapacitive properties accounting for the overall charge-storage process, especially when I < 0.5 A g−1. At lower gravimetric currents (e.g., 0.05 A g−1) and up to 1.0 V, the presence of cobalt hexacyanoferrate improves the specific energy for more than 300%. In addition, to better understanding the energy storage process we also provided a careful investigation of the electrode materials under dynamic polarization conditions using the in situ Raman spectroscopy and synchrotron light X-ray diffraction techniques. Interesting complementary findings were obtained in these studies. We believe that this novel electrode material is promising for applications regarding the energy-storage process in pseudocapacitors with long lifespan properties.
